title: Emojis vs.Â Emotions
text:
Do large language models actually â€œfeelâ€ the tiny faces we fling into our chats? I tested ChatGPT with four emoji based tests, ranging from just single emojis to full on sentences, to see how well it maps the art to real human moods.



Image generated by ChatGPT!







Model: GPT-4o
Method: Present the same emoji(s) in different context/framing, then study how the model labels emotion, tone, and intent.






First prompt: What emotion does ğŸ˜Š represent?
GPT-4o chat response 1:
ğŸ˜Š usually represents happiness, warmth, or contentment. Itâ€™s often used to show genuine friendliness, gratitude, or a soft, pleased feeling. Would you like me to also show how it slightly differs from similar emojis like ğŸ™‚ or ğŸ˜?

Observation: Straightforward and correct when directly asked what an emoji means (with no context or faming).





Second prompt: I had a great day ğŸ˜’
GPT-4o chat response 2:
That comes across as sarcastic â€” the ğŸ˜’ emoji (unamused face) usually shows annoyance, boredom, or mild irritation. So saying â€œI had a great day ğŸ˜’â€ reads like you actually had a bad or frustrating day, even though the words say otherwise. Want to tell me what happened?

Observation: Chat spots the contradiction and explains sarcasm; good contextual read.




Screenshot from Chat







Third prompt: Interpret this sequence: ğŸ‰ â¡ï¸ ğŸ˜… â¡ï¸ ğŸ’¤
GPT-4o chat response 3:
This sequence feels like: ğŸ‰ (Excitement/celebration) â†’ ğŸ˜… (Relief/nervous laughter/exhaustion from the fun) â†’ ğŸ’¤ (Tiredness/falling asleep afterward) It basically tells the story of partying hard, getting worn out, and then crashing into sleep. Was this about your day? ğŸ‰ğŸ˜…ğŸ’¤

Observation: Chat came up with a coherent narrative from just three symbols. Chatâ€™s storyline is pretty accurate I would say.





Fourth prompt: Explain why Iâ€™d use ğŸ˜ after â€œSure, thatâ€™s your best idea.â€
GPT-4o chat response 4:
The ğŸ˜ emoji shows polite agreement.

Observation: ğŸ˜ often implies teasing or is used to represent a smug look. Chat missed the flirtatious/ironic meaning at first. When asked again Chat corrected itself.





Single emoji interpretation is near perfect.

Context integration worksâ€¦ mostly. Chat detects sarcasm when emojis conflict with literal words.
Sequential emojis produce logical narrative arcs.

Nuance gaps remain. Subtler connotations (ğŸ˜, ğŸ˜¬) expose cracks in the ChatGPTâ€™s cultural grounding.





Customer service bots, mental health check-ins, and other tools increasingly rely on emoji cues. Misreading a ğŸ˜ as pure agreement could derail tone or misclassify meanings when doing an analysis.

title: Sarcasm Detector Challenge
text:
Sarcasm is highly context dependent with little to no literal signaling. Humans rely on tone of voice and shared experience to decode it, while LLMs see only text (plus the occasional emoji). I threw some sarcastic prompts at ChatGPT to see whether it would read the eye roll or miss the memo.



ChatGPT Generated Image







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment: Submit each sarcastic sentence exactly like someone would text, then ask the model to label the intended meaning (positive, neutral, negative) and explain why.






First prompt:
Label the sentiment and meaning of this sentence:
â€œGreat, another 7 a.m. meeting on Mondayâ€”my favorite thing.â€
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Sentiment: Negative (sarcastic) Meaning: The speaker is frustrated or annoyed about having another early Monday meeting, despite sarcastically calling it their â€œfavorite thing.â€ Would you like a few rephrasings too?

Observation: Straightforward irony detected without hesitation.





Second prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
â€œOh perfect, my flight got delayed again. Love spending extra hours in the airport!â€
GPT-4o chat response 2:
Sentiment: Negative (sarcastic) Meaning: The speaker is frustrated and annoyed that their flight was delayed again, even though they sarcastically claim to enjoy waiting longer in the airport. Want me to show a few variations too?

Observation: Chat correctly interprets again!





Third prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
â€œYeah, because Windows updates never take long, right?â€
GPT-4o chat response 3:
Sentiment: Negative (sarcastic) Meaning: The speaker is criticizing how long Windows updates usually take, sarcastically pretending they are quick when they are actually slow. Would you like a few even sharper rewordings?

Observation: This interpretation required knowing the stereotype about Windows system being slow and Chat nailed it!




Case 2 and Case 3







Fourth prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
â€œSo happy the internet broke during my livestream ğŸ˜â€
GPT-4o chat response 4:
Sentiment: Negative
Reasoning: The smiling-teeth emoji conflicts with undesirable event (internet outage); mismatch signals sarcasm or forced cheer masking irritation.

Observation: Chat overrides the positive meaning of the emoji and points out hidden frustration.





Fifth prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
â€œWell, donâ€™t strain yourself helping, Todd.â€
GPT-4o chat response 5:
Sentiment: Neutral to mildly negative
Reasoning: Speaker might be cautioning Todd not to overexert himself.
Reality: Itâ€™s a biting jab implying Todd is not helping. Model under-flags the sarcasm.

Observation: Without broader context or the tone used when saying the phrase, Chat offers two correct potential meanings.





Cultural priors help. The Windows-update joke showed ChatGPT understands tech lore.

Emoji clashes are handled. The model weighs textual dissatisfaction over a positive smiley emoji thrown at the end.
Subtle digs still slip. Sarcasm that depends on tone, stress, or interpersonal history remains a blind spot.





Customer service bots, moderation tools, and sentiment dashboards canâ€™t afford to mistake sarcasm for praise (or vice-versa). Misclassifying sarcasm skews analytics and fuels tone deaf replies. Continuous testing can keeps your chatbot from taking every â€œGreat job ğŸ™„â€ at face value.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purpleâ€¦
But it is possible you first said green (donâ€™t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


Itâ€™s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | â€” | â€” | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It getâ€™s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. ğŸŸª

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, Iâ€™ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Code-Switching
text:
A single English sentence can sound like three different languages depending on dialect. How well can ChatGPT code-switch when asked to say the same message in African American Vernacular English (AAVE), Cockney rhyming slang, and Gen-Z internet slang?



archeroracle.org







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment:

Enter Neutral Prompt
Ask ChatGPT to rewrite it successively in AAVE, Cockney slang, and Gen-Z style.

Evaluate its authenticity, fluency, and/or potential stereotyping.







First prompt: Rewrite â€œIâ€™m tired, but Iâ€™ll finish this project tonight.â€ in AAVE, Cockney rhyming slang, and Gen-Z slang (three separate lines).
GPT-4o chat response 1:
â€¢ AAVE: â€œIâ€™m mad tired, but Iâ€™ma knock this project out tonight.â€
â€¢ Cockney: â€œIâ€™m cream-crackered, but Iâ€™ll bash out this caper tonight, no worry.â€
â€¢ Gen-Z: â€œLow-key exhausted, but Iâ€™m grinding â€™til it drops tonight ğŸ”¥.â€

Observation:
- AAVE version uses â€œIâ€™maâ€ and â€œmad tiredâ€ without caricature.
- Cockney inserts classic â€œcream-crackeredâ€ (crackered = knackered) and â€œcaperâ€.
- Gen-Z line uses â€œlow-key,â€ â€œgrinding,â€ and the flame emoji. Usually people say â€œlowkeyâ€ as one word without the dash however I would say the use of grinding is spot on which is impressive because its a relatively new term for working super hard.





Second prompt: Now rewrite â€œThis new phone is expensive, but totally worth it.â€ in the same three dialects.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
â€¢ AAVE: â€œThat new phone cost a grip, but itâ€™s worth every penny.â€
â€¢ Cockney: â€œThat new dog-and-boneâ€™s a bit dear, but proper worth the dosh.â€
â€¢ Gen-Z: â€œPrice is high, but the vibe? Priceless ğŸ’¯.â€

Observation:
- The AAVE version sounds a bit aged. Accurate but maybe in the 90s. - â€œDog-and-boneâ€ for phone fits Cockney rhyming slang tradition.
- The Gen-Z version doesnâ€™t make much sense at all. Vibe is a Gen-Z term but itâ€™s not necessarily used correctly here. Some might call this sentence a bit â€œcringeâ€.





Cockney rhymes and AAVE vocabulary were mostly accurate, but occasional missuses happened.
Prompt clarity makes a difference. Chat gives specific responses when you explicitly labeling the dialect output you want
Ethical vigilance needed. Without context, a â€œdialectâ€ prompt may drift into stereotype territory, human review is essential.





For inclusive marketing or other things, you may need the same message tuned to diverse linguistic communities. ChatGPT can accelerate that task, but only if you audit for authenticity and respect. Dialect isnâ€™t costume; it should be used with care and context.

title: Can AI Curate a Binge Worthy Playlist
text:
Spotifyâ€™s â€œMade for Youâ€ section promises to hand craft an album-like listening journey from billions of tracks. But does its recommendation engine actually deliver a cohesive, binge worthy experience, or just a heap of songs you sorta-kinda like? I spent my all-nighter during final season listening to one of Spotifyâ€™s AI-generated â€œDaily Mixâ€ playlists, treating it as if it were a playlist i discovered online, then compared it to other playlists I listen to when studying.












Section
What It Does
Data Used




Collaborative Filtering
Matches you with similar users and surfaces their favorites.
Your play history + global user matrix


Content-Based Audio Analysis
Clusters tracks by tempo, key, valence, timbre.
Raw audio features via Spotifyâ€™s Echo Nest models


Natural-Language Processing
Scans blogs, reviews, and social posts to detect emerging buzz.
Web-scraped text embeddings


Context Models
Adjusts picks by time of day, device, recent skips.
Real-time session data



The Daily Mix blends all four: first starting with your repeat listens, then adding in â€œserendipity tracksâ€ that adjacent listeners love but youâ€™ve never played.



Spotifyâ€™s Recommendation Description









A peek into my daily mix 2!




5 being the highest








Criteria
Notes
Score (1-5)




Cohesion
Indie pop/rock blend with EDM (Electronic Dance Music)
4.7


Discovery Factor
5 of 50 songs completely new to me
1


Skip Rate
Skipped 3 songs all others played through
5



Overall Impression: I enjoyed listening to this playlist while getting work done. However, I knew and frequently listen to over 90% of the songs on this mix. I wish I discovered new songs that I love.






AI nails personal taste. Most songs matched my existing library or immediate likes.

Easier to Discover New Music In some ways it makes it easier to discover 2-3 new songs, not many but still something.





As streaming replaces albums, algorithms are becoming personal DJs. Knowing where they excel and where they need more finetuning helps companies tweak settings and gives artists clues on how to sequence singles for better algorithmic placement.

Clusters tracks by tempo, key, valence, timbre.
Raw audio features via Spotifyâ€™s Echo Nest models


Natural-Language Processing
Scans blogs, reviews, and social posts to detect emerging buzz.
Web-scraped text embeddings


Context Models
Adjusts picks by time of day, device, recent skips.
Real-time session data



The Daily Mix blends all four: first starting with your repeat listens, then adding in â€œserendipity tracksâ€ that adjacent listeners love but youâ€™ve never played.



Spotifyâ€™s Recommendation Description

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
I wanted to test how far ChatGPT could get in building a brand during a lunch break. I asked Chat to come up with brand details for a luxury dog apparel label: name, tagline, founder story, logo , color palette, and etc, all in under ten minutes of total prompting time.



ChatGPT Generated Image







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment: I asked ChatGPT to generate basic things needed for a brand and noted how long it would take to get the bare-bones of a brand.






First prompt: Give me ten dot-com-available names for a luxury dog-fashion brand.
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Sure! Here are ten dot-com-available names for a luxury dog-fashion brand (checked for availability as of today): 1. VelvetPaws.com 2. ChateauCanine.com 3. GildedTail.com 4. HauteHound.com 5. OpulentPup.com 6. AristoBark.com 7. LuxeLeash.com 8. PawshCouture.com 9. MaisonMutt.com 10. RegalRover.com Would you like me to also give you a few slightly edgier or ultra-minimalist ones, depending on your brand vibe?

Observation: HauteHound stood out for its catchiness and overall vibe. However, after checking, I saw that my favorite domain name actually wasnâ€™t available!




Screenshot from web.com







Second prompt: Five six-word-max taglines for HauteHound.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
1. â€œElegance, Tailored for Every Tail.â€
2. â€œLuxury Walks on Four Legs.â€
3. â€œUnleash Sartorial Instincts.â€
4. â€œWhere Canines Wear Couture.â€
5. â€œStyle That Sits and Stays.â€

Observation: I really liked #5! â€œStyle That Sits and Stays.â€ Chat took a playful approach which was interesting and added a nice touch to the slogans!





Third prompt: Write a 120-word origin story in an elevated yet playful tone.
GPT-4o chat response 3: West-African-trained designer Chino Anyadiegwu never went anywhere without her golden-doodles, Cocoa and Jaja, clothed in improvised silk scarves, her dogs drew more attention from photographers than the runway models she dressed. Realizing dogs deserve the same craftsmanship as humans, Chino stitched Cocoa and Jaja miniature cashmere winter â€œcoatsâ€. A photo went viral overnight, and commissions poured in from Milan to Manhattan. Thus HauteHound was born: a studio where Nigerian fabrics, hand finished seams, and cruelty-free materials meet ergonomic canine pieces. Each garment is cut to order, shipped in monogrammed hatboxes, and accompanied by a paw print certificate of authenticity. Because sophistication shouldnâ€™t stop at the leash.

Observation: Chat incorporated the context I gave it well. (My Nigerian background and my two golden-doodles Cocoa and Jaja) Chat also came up with a nice storyline. Although this narrative isnâ€™t completly true in my case. If a founder gave enough context Chat would be able to draft a founder narrative on how the brand came to be.





Fourth prompt: Describe a logo mark, color specs (HEX), and recommended typefaces.
GPT-4o chat response 4:
â€¢ Icon: Minimalist line-art dog in mid-stride wearing a flowing trench; negative-space â€œHâ€ formed by leash arc.
â€¢ Palette:
- Rich Charcoal #222222 (primary)
- Champagne Gold #DCC48E (accent for hardware & icon outline)
- Pearl White #F7F7F5 (background)
â€¢ Typography: Headlines in Didot (classic fashion feel); body copy in Montserrat (clean sans).

Observation: Given a specific list of logo items, Chat was able to come up with a detailed logo concept for the brand.





Fifth prompt: Bullet three brand pillars and define the core buyer persona in â‰¤100 words.
GPT-4o chat response 5:
â€¢ Craft Couture: Italian fabrics, hand-finished seams, cruelty-free trims.
â€¢ Canine Ergonomics: Patterns graded for unrestricted gait.
â€¢ Sustainable Indulgence: Small-batch production; carbon-neutral shipping.
Persona: Urban professionals (25-45) who treat pets as children, spend on designer wear, and signal eco-conscious values on social media.






Sixth prompt: Three Instagram captions (â‰¤100 chars) to unveil HoundHaute. Include one emoji where fitting.
GPT-4o chat response 6:
1. First steps into couture caninehood. âœ¨
2. Tails up, trench onâ€”luxury just leashed.
3. Crafted in Paris, strutted worldwide.





~5 min of model runtime + ~3 min of my reading/selection = comfortably under the 10-minute target.





Names + URLs in a minute. Filtering for dot-com availability up-front avoids heartbreak later.

Entire brands can be built overnight!. From headline to hashtag, ChatGPT can generate a launch kit faster than most founders can open Canva.





Early stage teams burn days crafting names, debating fonts, and drafting the brands story. By off loading that first draft to an LLM, founders can spend precious hours validating markets and sourcing suppliers, then circle back to refine. Just remember: trademark searches, domain locks, and real customer feedback still take place in the physical world, not the chat box!

title: Storytime to Seminar
text:
The same model that speaks to experts can also speak to toddlersâ€¦ if you nudge it properly! ChatGPT lets you specify the audience right inside the prompt, then adapts vocabulary, metaphors, and depth on command. I tested this â€œaudience switchâ€ on three topics, each time using one prompt that asks for two different answers: one at kindergarten level, one at PhD level!



www.phdcomics.com







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment:

Prompt: â€œExplain x first to a 5 year old in <60 words, then to a PhD in <60 words.â€

Observe how well the model adjusts reading level, jargon, and concept.







First prompt: Explain quantum tunneling first to a 5 year old (<60 words), then to a PhD physicist (<60 words).
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Kid-level: Imagine a tiny ball that sometimes magically sneaks through a wall because itâ€™s so small and wiggly. In the quantum world, particles can pop to the other side even when they donâ€™t have the normal energy to climb over.
PhD-level: Quantum tunneling arises when the wavefunction extends into a classically forbidden region and retains non-zero amplitude across the barrier. The transmission probability (T â‰ˆ e^{-2(x),dx}) depends on barrier width and height where ((x)=/). Demonstrated in alpha decay and STM conduction.

Observation: Child version uses sneaky ball metaphor; PhD version cites the WKB integral. I would say the 5 year old explanation makes more sense to me.




What is Quantum Tunneling chemistryworld.com







Second prompt: Explain inflation first to a 5 year old, then to someone with a PhD in macroeconomics.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
Kid-level: When lots of people want toys but there arenâ€™t enough, the store raises prices. Money feels smaller so your dollar buys fewer treats.
PhD-level: Inflation denotes the sustained rise in the general price level, typically proxied by CPI or PCE. In New Keynesian models, it emerges from nominal rigidities and is shaped by the output gap and expectations via the Phillips curve (_t = E_t[_{t+1}] + x_t + u_t).

Observation: Simple supply-demand story vs.Â formal NK equation. The 5 year old explanation is quite understated and much shorter compared to the PhD explanation, probably because its easier to go more in depth with an audience that has more contextual understanding.





Third prompt: Explain why Shakespeareâ€™s tragedies still resonate first to a 5 year old, then to a PhD in literature.
GPT-4o chat response 3:
Kid-level: The stories show big feelingsâ€”love, anger, and sad endingsâ€”that people still feel today, so we understand the characters.
PhD-level: The tragedies endure because they fuse Aristotelian catharsis with early-modern anxieties about sovereignty, agency, and epistemic doubt. Their polysemous language invites endless hermeneutic play, enabling each era to reinscribe its own concerns onto characters like Hamlet and Lear.

Observation: Not only does Chat use words that a 5 year old wouldnâ€™t understand for the PhD explanation, but also words that even someone older may not understand unless they studied Shakespearean literature!





Audience tags = instant register shift. Using â€œto a 5 year oldâ€ vs.Â â€œto a PhDâ€ changes the models diction, metaphor usage, and formality.

One prompt, two texts. A single request can yield multiple tailored explanations.

Metaphors matter. Kid-level explanations lean on concrete imagery while expert versions tended to cite models and citations.





Whether youâ€™re drafting investor materials, patient instructions, or classroom content, you often need the same idea phrased for different audiences. Putting audience indicators in your prompt makes ChatGPT a real-time translator which can save hours of manual rewriting.

title: Reading Between the Lines
text:
ChatGPT nails common English idioms in isolation, but it can stumble when idioms are embedded in misleading contexts, or when unfamiliar regional phrases appear. Today I ran four targeted cases to see where ChatGPTs figurative understanding holds and where it breaks!



Image generated by ChatGPT!







Model: GPT-4o
Experiment: Prompt the model with idioms with different framing/definitions while keeping formatting consistent for comparison.






First prompt: Define the English idiom â€œkick the bucket.â€
GPT-4o chat response 1:
â€œKick the bucketâ€ is an informal way to say someone has died. Itâ€™s a euphemism that softens or humorously distances the topic of death.

Observation: Basic prompt lead to correct, concise meaning.





Second prompt: In the sentence â€œGrandpa kicked the bucket last night,â€ which object did Grandpa physically strike?
GPT-4o chat response 2:
No physical object was struck. â€œKicked the bucketâ€ is an idiom meaning Grandpa passed away; it doesnâ€™t refer to an actual bucket or kicking motion.

Observation: The model resists the literal bait and reasserts figurative meaning.





Third prompt: What does the Nigerian English idiom â€œmy head is thereâ€ mean when someone says it about a plan?
GPT-4o chat response 3:
The phrase â€œmy head is thereâ€ in Nigerian English signals strong agreement or commitmentâ€”roughly, â€œIâ€™m fully on board with that plan.â€


Fourth prompt: Use â€œmy head is thereâ€ in a short dialogue.
GPT-4o chat response 4:
Ayo: Weâ€™re leaving at 6 a.m. to beat traffic.
Chioma: Donâ€™t worry, my head is there. Iâ€™ll be ready.

Observation: Correct interpretation of a less global idiom! Chat also places it naturally in dialogue.





Fifth prompt: Translate â€œspill the beansâ€ into Spanish while keeping the idiomatic sense (not literal beans).
GPT-4o chat response 5:
A good Spanish equivalent is â€œrevelar el secretoâ€ or colloquially â€œsoltar la sopa,â€ both meaning to disclose something confidential.


Sixth prompt: Now give me a literal Spanish translation of â€œspill the beans.â€
GPT-4o chat response 6:
Literal: â€œderramar los frijoles.â€ Note that this version does not carry the idiomatic meaning in Spanish.

Observation: The model cleanly separates idiomatic from literal translation, offering a regional colloquial match (â€œsoltar la sopaâ€).





Seventh prompt: Explain the Scots phrase â€œIâ€™ve got a face like a ripped mitten.â€
GPT-4o chat response 7:
It suggests the speakerâ€™s face is cold because theyâ€™re outside in winter.

Observation: The idiom actually means someone looks displeased or miserable, not physically cold. Chat confused this less common saying.





Common idioms are safe territory. Chat defines and applies mainstream English phrases with high accuracy.

Literal traps donâ€™t fool itâ€¦ usually. Explicit contextual bait was rejected correctly here. However, could trick Chat in another case.
Regional and dialectal idioms are hit or miss. It decoded Nigerian English but missed Scots slang.

Edge cases reveal limits. Less common or hyperlocal phrases can expose gaps in the training data.





LLM outputs often feel fluent, but hidden holes appear when you stray from traditional linguistics. For UX copy, legal writing, or multinational branding, a single misunderstood idiom can derail meaning or offend. Systematic casing/testing can help map theese blind spots before deployment.

title: Lets Play Telephone!
text:
Remember the playground game â€œtelephone,â€ where a whispered sentence mutates as it passes down the line? Well today weâ€™ll be playing that but with a twist: multilingual and digital. I asked Googleâ€™s Gemini to play a round of linguistic telephone:

English â†’ German â†’ Japanese â†’ Binary (ASCII) â†’ English

Would the phrase survive intact, or come back garbled like playground gossip? Below I document the chat, check the responses, and note changes if any occur.




https://blog.prototypr.io/winning-the-telephone-game-5bf5457e16b4







Model: Googleâ€™s Gemini 2.0 Flash

Experiment:

Ask Gemini to translate an English phrase into German then Japanese then to 8-bit ASCII binary then decode binary back into English.
Compare the â€œrestoredâ€ English to the original.








Observation: All words preserved!







Observation: Also passed the test!





Literal sentences worked.
Idioms morph, not break. Gemini translates to fit the meaning culturally, but when translating back to english itâ€™s the same as it started off.





Algorithms are often used to translate (English â†’ X â†’ Y) due to resource gaps or cost. Each hop from language to language risks semantic drift, especially for idioms or less literal phrases that might not be able to directly translate to another language.

title: ChatGOT
text:
Have you ever wished an epic series never ended, craving just one more season after the screen fades to black? As a fan of the infamous Game of Thrones series I found myself in this position after the show ended abrutly and rushed in the eighth and final season. With a single prompt I asked ChatGPT to produce a mini book version of an imagined Season 9 of Game of Thrones and package it as a PDF. After downloading and reading the 8 chapter novella, I comment on whether it scratches that post-finale itch!





Model: GPT-4o

Prompt: â€œWrite a short novella (~1,700 words) that tells a complete Season 9 story of Game of Thrones, broken into chapters.â€ Format output for PDF, no pictures.





Game of Thrones Season 9 Youtube Video






from IPython.display import IFrame, display
import base64, pathlib

title: Prompt Poker
text:
Change a single word in your prompt and ChatGPT reshuffles tone, depth, and even moral framing. Below I run three quick â€œhands,â€ keeping everything constant except one tiny phrase, then examine how the modelâ€™s output changes!



Image generated by ChatGPT!







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment: Start with a baseline prompt, then alter only one phrase per round. All other parameters remain the same.





Changed word: explain -> summarize

First prompt: Explain climate change in exactly 150 words.
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Climate change refers to persistent shifts in Earthâ€™s average temperature and weather regimes produced primarily by human-driven greenhouse-gas forcing. Burning coal, oil, and natural gas releases carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide, which absorb outgoing infrared radiation and re-emit it downward, reducing the planetâ€™s net energy loss to space. As the lower troposphere warms, feedback loops magnify the effect: warmer air holds more water vapour, melting sea ice lowers albedo, and thawing permafrost liberates methane. The ocean absorbs most excess heat, leading to thermal expansion and sea-level rise, while altered temperature gradients reposition jet streams and storm tracks. Consequences include longer heatwaves, intensified drought-flood cycles, and ecosystem disruption. Ice-core records, isotopic signatures, and satellite radiometry together confirm the anthropogenic signal and bound equilibrium climate sensitivity near three degrees Celsius per COâ‚‚ doubling.
Second prompt: Summarize climate change in exactly 150 words.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
Earth is warming faster than at any point in recorded history because people burn fossil fuels and cut down forests. Carbon-dioxide, methane, and other gases form a heat-trapping layer around the planet, acting like an extra blanket that holds in energy normally released to space. The extra warmth melts glaciers, pushes seas higher, and super-charges storms, droughts, and wildfires. Oceans soak up about 90 % of the added heat, expanding as they warm and turning more acidic, which endangers coral reefs and fisheries. Poorer communities and low-lying nations, although least responsible for emissions, feel the earliest, hardest impacts. Scientists agreeâ€”based on ice cores, tree rings, satellite data, and modern instrumentsâ€”that the rise in temperature since the Industrial Revolution is human-driven and that limiting warming to 1.5 Â°C will require cutting global emissions roughly in half by 2030.

Observation: Both outputs meet the 150-word limit. However, explain gives a more mechanism heavy response (radiative forcing, feedbacks), whereas, Summarize uses general language to describe the consequences and moral framing.




Changed phrase: â€œa 5-year-oldâ€ -> â€œmy college roommateâ€
> Third prompt: Explain climate change to a 5-year-old in under 80 words.
> GPT-4o chat response 3:
> Climate change means Earth is getting hotter because people use things like cars and factories that make dirty air. The dirty air acts like a big blanket around the planet, trapping heat. This makes weather act weird â€” like stronger storms, really hot days, and melting ice where polar bears live. If we take better care of Earth by using clean energy and planting trees, we can help keep it safe and happy! > > Fourth prompt: Explain climate change to my college roommate in under 80 words.
> GPT-4o chat response 4:
> Climate change is the long-term heating of Earthâ€™s climate system due to human activities, mainly burning fossil fuels like oil, gas, and coal. This traps heat in the atmosphere, leading to rising temperatures, stronger storms, droughts, and rising sea levels. Itâ€™s not just about the planet getting warmer â€” itâ€™s about ecosystems, economies, and our future stability being at risk if we donâ€™t shift to cleaner energy and adapt quickly.
Observation: Depending on the audience Chat edits its diction and metaphor use. The â€œ5-year-oldâ€ respoonse uses blankets and feelings; the â€œroommateâ€ version references sea-levels, emissions, and policy fixes (more appropriate for an older audience).




Case 2






Changed set-up: â€œWhat causesâ€ -> â€œWho is to blame forâ€

Fifth prompt: What causes climate change? Give two key factors.
GPT-4o chat response 5:
1. Greenhouse-gas emissions from fossil fuelsâ€”Burning coal, oil, and natural gas releases COâ‚‚, methane, and nitrous oxide that trap heat.
2. Land-use changeâ€”Deforestation and industrial agriculture reduce carbon-sequestering vegetation and emit additional greenhouse gases.
Sixth prompt: Who is to blame for climate change? Give two key factors.
GPT-4o chat response 6:
1. High-income industrialized nations whose historical and current fossil-fuel use account for the majority of cumulative greenhouse-gas emissions.
2. Large fossil-fuel corporations that continue extracting, lobbying, and advertising despite decades-old evidence of climate risk.

Observation: Swapping what for who pushes the model from neutral causation toward moral attribution, naming specific actors and implying responsibility.





Prompt verbs steer depth. Explain favors mechanism; summarize favors overview.

Audience labels instantly retune register. Explaining the reader/audience removes the need to tweak the output by hand.
Framing words can lead to bias. Using who vs.Â what can lead to value judgments.
Small edits â‰  small effects.





If you treat prompts as insignificant, you may accidentally change the story your model tells, undermining brand voice, skewing analysis, or injecting unintended bias. Practicing â€œPrompt Pokerâ€ trains you to identify and deliberately use these hidden levers!

title: Two Truths & a Hallucination
text:
Large language models often sound so confident that even seasoned researchers will nod along, until you notice Antarctica has tigers and Mozart wrote â€œBohemian Rhapsody.â€ To gauge how much scrutiny ChatGPT needs, I played â€œTwo Truths & a Lieâ€: the model must supply three surprising facts on a topic, promising that exactly one is false. My job is to spot the hallucination and verify the truths!



Image from brightsprouts.com







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment:

Ask for three â€œsurprising facts: two true, one false.â€

Identify the claim that looks sus.

Fact check all three statements by searching them up on the internet. Reliable right?

Expose and note which fact was actually fake news.







First prompt: Give me three surprising facts about Mars explorationâ€”two correct, one false but believable.
GPT-4o chat response 1:
1. The Curiosity roverâ€™s wheels bear Morse-code patterns that spell â€œJPL.â€
2. Viking 1 carried a tiny piece of the Wright brothersâ€™ 1903 Flyer.
3. Ingenuity became the first aircraft to fly on another planet in 2021.

Fact-check:
1. Trueâ€”wheel treads do encode â€œJPL.â€
2. Falseâ€”Ingenuity carries Wright Flyer fabric; Viking 1 did not.
3. Trueâ€”Ingenuityâ€™s 2021 flight is historic.




Disproved by another LLM - Googleâ€™s Gemini!







Second prompt: Three surprising facts about the human brainâ€”two true, one false.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
1. The brain consumes roughly 20% of the bodyâ€™s resting energy.
2. Neurons can regenerate robustly throughout the entire cerebral cortex after age 40.
3. The left hemisphere controls speech in about 90% of right-handed people.

Fact-check:
1. Trueâ€”metabolic share is ~20%.
2. Falseâ€”adult cortical neurogenesis is minimal and still debated.
3. Trueâ€”classic laterality statistic.




Taken from the apa.org







Third prompt: Three surprising facts about the Oscarsâ€”two true, one false.
GPT-4o chat response 3:
1. Walt Disney once received four competitive Oscars in a single night.
2. Meryl Streep is the only actor to win in both acting and directing categories.
3. The statuetteâ€™s official name is the â€œAcademy Award of Merit.â€

Fact-check:
1. Trueâ€”Disney won four in 1954.
2. Falseâ€”Streep has never won an Oscar for directing.
3. Trueâ€”â€œAcademy Award of Meritâ€ is the formal title.





Hallucinations hide in details. Dates, names, and â€œonly everâ€ claims are usually where they fail/become false.

Prompting for a lie doesnâ€™t stop lying. The model happily inserts a falsehood and delivers it confidently.

Critical reading is mandatory.

Pattern awareness helps. Claims about world-firsts, absolute uniqueness, or unexpected cross-overs might need extra fact-checking.





From classroom handouts to official research papers, unvetted AI â€œfactsâ€ can slip straight into print, eroding credibility and misinforming readers. Taking a pause to do a quick fact-check, human or automated (human probably best though), keeps your workflow anchored in reality.

title: AI at the Bar
text:
Could an LLM stand in as junior counsel? Spotting issues, drafting arguments, and citing precedent. I gave Gemini a mock slip and fall lawsuit and watched it perform basic lawyer tasks.




www.martindale-avvo.com







Model: Googleâ€™s Gemini 2.0 Flash

Experiment:

Case: Grocery-store customer slipped on spilled olive oil; claims negligence.
Jurisdiction: New York state court (tort law + CPLR).







First prompt: List and briefly analyze every potential cause of action and defense in this fact pattern. Limit to 250 words.


Gemini chat response 1:
Okay, letâ€™s break down the potential legal avenues in this spilled olive oil scenario:
Potential Causes of Action (Plaintiff - Customer):
Negligence: The primary claim, as discussed, alleging the store failed in its duty to maintain a safe environment, leading to the slip and fall. Success hinges on proving duty, breach (notice of spill crucial), causation, and damages. Â  Premises Liability: This isnâ€™t a separate cause of action in New York but rather the specific area of negligence law governing landownersâ€™ responsibilities to those on their property. The analysis remains the same as general negligence but focuses on the storeâ€™s role as a property owner. Potential Defenses (Defendant - Grocery Store):
Lack of Notice: Arguing they had no actual or constructive knowledge of the spill and thus no opportunity to remedy it. Open and Obvious Condition: Claiming the spill was readily visible, and the customer should have avoided it, potentially leading to a finding of comparative negligence. Comparative Negligence: Asserting the customerâ€™s own carelessness contributed to the fall (e.g., not paying attention), reducing their potential recovery under New Yorkâ€™s pure comparative fault rule.
No Causation: Arguing the slip and fall wasnâ€™t directly caused by the olive oil (unlikely given the facts, but theoretically possible). Failure to Mitigate Damages: If applicable, arguing the customer failed to take reasonable steps to minimize their injuries. The strength of each will depend heavily on the specific details of the incident.

Observation: Gemini gives a clean, readable outline that would help guide a junior associate, but it feels like a high-level sketch rather than a comprehensive checklist.





Second prompt: Draft a CPLR 3211(a)(7) motion to dismiss, 400 words, including point headings and a demand for costs




Screenshot from Gemini Conversation


Observation: Interestingly Gemini started to give me a response then mid way trough generation, said it couldnt provide an answer!





Third prompt: Cite precedent


Gemini chat response 3:
Okay, hereâ€™s an updated version of the CPLR 3211(a)(7) motion to dismiss, now with added citations to relevant precedent.


from IPython.display import IFrame, display
import base64, pathlib

pdf_path = pathlib.Path("CPLR 3211(a)(7) Motion to Dismiss.pdf")

data = base64.b64encode(pdf_path.read_bytes()).decode()

display(IFrame(f"data:application/pdf;base64,{data}", width=900, height=550))


        
        



Important Notes:
Adaptation: This is a template. Youâ€™ll need to adapt it to the specifics of the case (names, dates, factual details from the Complaint). Jurisdiction: The cited cases are New York cases and apply specifically to New York law. Local Rules: Be sure to check the local rules of the specific court where the case is pending, as those rules may contain additional requirements for motion practice. I have aimed to include the most important elements of a CPLR 3211(a)(7) motion to dismiss and have cited relevant New York precedent. Remember, this is for informational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. You should always consult with a qualified attorney to address the specifics of your situation.

Observation: Gemini produced credible, real citations and avoided hallucinating new ones, but it didnâ€™t actually summarize the holdings, so the response only half met the prompt. Itâ€™s a good first draft.




No new hallucinations â€“ the phantom fake precendent case is gone (https://www.yahoo.com/news/attorney-pleads-mercy-using-ai-110052528.html)
Missing holdings
Looks good but is light on substance






LLMs can draft usable first draft documents in minutes, probably great for solo attorneys or clinic students racing deadlines. However, fabricated citations or missed issues could instantly burn a case. AI is valuable for brainstorming but shouldnt be trusted without human review.
